thread.title: More money, more game time for Jarryd Hayne at San Francisco 49ers, Andrew Bogut believes
thread.title_full: More money, more game time for Jarryd Hayne at San Francisco 49ers, Andrew Bogut believes

author: Jamie Marcuson
title: More money, more game time for Jarryd Hayne at San Francisco 49ers, Andrew Bogut believes
text:

Jarryd Hayne's crash in 49ers' loss Jarryd Hayne is run over by his own teammate during the San Fransisco 49ers game last against the Green Bay Packers.
PT0M26S 620 349 Jarryd Hayne is getting fewer opportunities in games because he is on less money than his teammates, Australian NBA star Andrew Bogut believes.
Bogut, who has befriended Hayne during his journey from the NRL to the San Francisco 49ers, said American sports reward those on higher salaries with more game time.
"He is just waiting now, playing behind some guys that are making more money than he is, and we know how that works in pro sports," the Golden State Warriors centre told the San Francisco Chronicle .
Waiting: Jarryd Hayne is learning the craft. Photo: Getty Images
Bogut texted Hayne when he originally transitioned to the NFL, despite not knowing him, to try help him settle into his new surroundings.
Advertisement "I just reached out to him once he came here, he was by himself â€¦ he didn't really know anybody, so I just tried to catch up with him," he said. "(I wanted to) make him feel a little bit at home, come and hear an Australian accent."
Bogut still feels that the US audience is yet to appreciate how big Hayne was in rugby league.
Flying high: Golden State Warriors centre Andrew Bogut. Photo: AP
"He's one of the best players ever to play rugby in the world. He was top five and he was in his prime. People don't understand he was the equivalent to LeBron James in Australia for rugby," he said.
Hayne's switch has been compared to Michael Jordan's famous, if very short-lived, baseball career in the early 1990s. Bogut said that while the comparison is apt, Hayne has faced a far tougher transition.
"You look at MJ, he had actually played baseball, but this guy had never played football, never wore shoulder pads," he said. "To come out and not only make the team but to actually get playing time is pretty impressive."
Bogut believes that despite being on a lower salary, Hayne is still in the frame for a great career in the NFL. "He just has to keep working and he'll eventually get his shot."
